description: From Middle English trindel (“wheel, roller”), from Old English tryndel (“circle, ring”), from Proto-Germanic *trundilaz (“ring, hoop”), equivalent to trend +‎ -le. Akin to Low German tründeln (“to roll”). More at trend.

entries.meaning: (dialectal) a wheel, especially of a wheelbarrow.
A piece of wood, etc., laid between the cords and boards of a book to flatten before cutting.

verbs.description: trindle (third-person singular simple present trindles, present participle trindling, simple past and past participle trindled)
